title: Hayling Billy Trail Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Hugh Venables / Hayling Billy Trail, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The fence separates the horse route (right) from the pedestrian and bike path on the left.

images.title: Basher Eyre / Hayling Billy Trail near Montgomery Road, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The trail near Montgomery Road Taken on a lovely, if crisp, December morning.

images.title: Basher Eyre / Stream running alongside the Hayling Billy Trail, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Stream running alongside the Hayling Billy Trail

images.title: Basher Eyre / Looking inland along the Hayling Billy Trail, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking inland along the Hayling Billy Trail

images.title: Hugh Venables / Mudflats, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Mudflats From close to the car park at the northern end of the Hayling Billy trail. The Road bridge to Hayling Island can also be seen in the background.

images.title: Espresso Addict / Field by Langstone Harbour, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Field by Langstone Harbour. Narrow arable field between Langstone Harbour and the Hayling Billy Trail. The field level is around 3 feet above the foreshore at this point and is subject to frequent erosion. A narrow strip of deciduous woodland (right; not shown on the OS 1:25,000) forms the northern field boundary and a drainage channel (not visible) runs along this edge of the field. The grassy field margin (centre) is used by walkers and cyclists as an alternative to the trail, but is not a right of way

images.title: Espresso Addict / Low tide on Langstone foreshore, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Low tide on Langstone foreshore. View north at low tide showing the pebble beach, narrow strip of sand and mudflats typical of this area of Langstone foreshore.

images.title: Espresso Addict / Reeds and trees, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Reeds and trees. This small, low-lying field adjacent to Langstone Harbour was salt marsh in the 1980s. Several drainage channels have been dug and the predominant vegetation is now reeds. The line of trees on the field boundary suggests the prevailing wind comes from the sea (to the left).

description: This popular cycling and walking trail uses the Hayling Billy Coastal Path which runs along the west coast of Hayling Island near Havant. The trail gives fabulous views of Langstone Harbour which is an internationally important site for its wildfowl and wading birds. Also watch out for brent geese, oyster catchers and dunlin in winter. The route is very flat and entirely off road so is ideal for families looking for a safe traffic free cycle ride or for walkers looking for a pleasant waterside stroll. This route links nicely with the Portsea Island Explorer if you'd like to continue your outing. To further extend your walking try our Hayling Island Coastal Walk and explore the coast around the southern section of the island. You could also head west to Portsea Island and pick up the Solent Way and explore the coast around Portsmouth and Southsea, Gosport and Lee on Solent. The Shipwrights Way cycling and walking trail runs along the trail too. It can be followed all the way into Portsmouth in one direction or you can head north up on to the South Downs to visit Queen Elizabeth Forest Park and Alice Holt Forest .
